didyouknow.text: A total of 13.54kg of cigarette butts were collected by Saving Our Blue during cleanups held in 2021.
A total of 11.5 tonnes (11,535.52kg) of recyclable waste was collected by Saving Our Blue during cleanups held in 2021.
A total of 3.4 tonnes (3,398.15kg) of recyclable was collected by Saving Our Blue during cleanups in 2021.

What is Saving our Blue? Saving our Blue is an Environmental awareness Campaign initiated by the Ministry for the Environment Climate Change and Planning to save our seas by reducing the consumption of single-use-plastic items.

What is the Campaign’s mission? The Saving our Blue Campaign aims at informing citizens about the Single-use-Plastic Strategy to limit the use of single-use-plastic items and reduce plastic waste generation - i.e marine litter in our sea.
When did the Campaign start? The Saving Our Blue Campaign was launched by the Ministry for the Environment, Climate Change and Planning on 8th June 2019 to celebrate World Oceans Day.

What has been done throughout the Campaign? The Saving Our Blue’s Campaign embarked on a number of different outreach initiatives and programmes to raise awareness on marine litter, from beach clean-ups to surveys and educational activities in schools.

How can people join the Campaign? Everyone can volunteer to be part of the Saving Our Blue beach clean-ups which take place mostly during summer, however one can form a group and send a message on the saving our blue facebook page for guidance and assistance on planning a seperate clean up.

Follow Saving Our Blue on Facebook and Instagram and keep updated with initiatives and latest news. Those who have a sustainable idea can pledge to safeguard the coastal and marine life around Malta and Gozo.
What are the main messages of the Campaign? The Saving our Blue messages are focused on encouraging people to be proactive and embrace a more sustainable lifestyle.
Maggie the sea turtle was rescued by Nature Trust in June 2019. She had serious damages to her flippers because of ghost nets and marine debris.
Maggie is the Saving Our Blue’s hero with a mission in mind to spread awarness on marine pollution.
Through her various adventures, Meggie shows both the harms of plastic litter on marine ecosystems as well as the wonders of our underwater environment.
Maggie calls everyone to take action now, as tomorrow can be too late.

Maggie loves addressing children and telling them stories about her underwater adventures. Maggie thinks that children are our future’s hope and encourages them to adopt more thoughtful and sustainable behaviours to protect marine life.
Sharks can be found in Marine Protected Areas around Malta and Gozo.
The Red Coral (Corallium rubrum) was found at a depth of 1,016 meters in Malta’s waters.
Marine caves and reefs are important habitats because they are hotspots for marine biodiversity.
Just one square metre of Posidonia seagrass produces as much oxygen as a hectare of the Amazon rainforest.
Posidonia meadows are some of the world's oldest organisms. These have been around for an estimated 100,000 years.
Turtles and dolphins are found in Maltese Marine protected areas.
The three seabirds found in Maltese MPAs are the Scopoli’s shearwater (Calonectris diomedea), the Yelkouan shearwater (Puffinus yelkouan) and the European storm petrel (Hydrobates pelagicus).
Pretty Bay and Saint Georges Bay are the only two popular sandy beaches not found within the designated Marine Protected Areas in Malta.
During the peak of the COVID-10 pandemic, turtles nested more in the northern sandy beaches in Malta.  This was attributed to less human activities which have a direct impact on marine wildlife.

Climate change has an impact on our Marine Protected Areas and sandy beaches because glaciers are melting in the Arctic, resulting in sea level rise. Therefore our fragile sandy beaches are threatened.
Since humans are producing more CO2, our oceans are becoming more acidic and as a result marine life will find it more difficult to adapt to these changes.
MPAs (Marine Protected Areas) are geared at maintaining or achieving Favourable Conservation Status of habitats and species listed in the Habitats and Birds Directives, respectively.

A number of MPAs have been designated for Posidonia beds. These not only  provide a vital marine habitat for numerous fauna, but have also a significant role as a carbon sink, absorbing carbon dioxide, storing it as carbon, and helping to alleviate the effects of climate change.
Malta has reached an important milestone through the designation of 4,138KM2 as MPAs.
Malta’s marine Natura 2000 network encompasses 18 sites, these are equivalent to more than 35% of Malta’s Fisheries Management Zone!

Within Malta’s MPA network one can find various habitats and species, amongst which, sea caves, reefs, sandbanks, Posidonia meadows, loggerhead turtles, Maltese top-shells, protected seabirds and bottlenose dolphins.
Natura 2000 is a network of core breeding and resting sites for rare and threatened species, and some rare natural habitat types.
The aim of the Natura 2000 network is to ensure the long-term survival of Europe’s most valuable and threatened species and habitats, listed under the Birds and Habitats Directives
Did you know that turtles often mistake plastic bags as jellyfish?

Did you know that the Neptune seagrass is classified as a pioneering species? This means that where it grows it stabilizes the sediment and attracts other plants and animals that eventually form very complex ecosystems.

Did you know that reefs are considered as biodiversity hotspots? They host a number of species, including algae, corals, sponges, molluscs, crustaceans and fish. In view of this, these habitats are afforded protection through a number of legal instruments.
Did you know that Bottlenose dolphins range between 2.8 to 4m in length and can live up to 50 years of age?
Did you know that loggerhead turtles can weigh up to 180kg?
